pullRequest.body:
This is a rewrite of `JacobiTheta/TwoVariable.lean`, adding a number of new results needed for Hurwitz and Dirichlet L-series.

The main addition is developing the theory of the `z`-derivative of the theta function, as an object of study in its own right (functional equations, periodicity, holomorphy etc) – this is needed to prove analytic continuation + functional equations for odd Dirichlet characters. 

We also add a number of new results about the existing `jacobiTheta2` function:
- converses of all the convergence statements (showing the series are *never* convergent if tau is outside the upper half-plane), which allows hypotheses to be removed from several results further downstream
- differentiability in both variables jointly, not just each variable separately as before.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]

-->
- [x] depends on: #11980

nodes.body:
Nice work!
I'll try to go through the proofs in more detail later, but so far it looks good to me.
Thanks for the very thorough review! I should hopefully have some time to look at these comments tomorrow evening.

Hi Michael,

I've implemented the changes you suggested, and done what I could to speed up the slow parts. There are still a few steps that are far slower than they ought to be; I will try asking on zulip if anyone has any suggestions about these.

On my system, compilation of `JacobiTheta/TwoVariable.lean` (at the current version, commit `bf62a22`) takes about 30 seconds. Merging #11980 brings this down to 26 seconds. This is not quite as much of a speedup as adding Michael's list of explicit custom instances (23 sec on my machine), but it's not too far off. 

I think merging in the long list of explicit instances would probably be judged as contravening mathlib's "house style" (especially given the conclusion of the recent zulip debate "To automate or not to automate?", where several prominent members of the community argued strongly that we should use automated systems whenever possible and tolerate some slow-down as a result). Other than that, I don't think there's much more that can be done to speed it up.

May I suggest that we wait on #11980, and when that is merged, we merge this as it is?

> On my system, compilation of `JacobiTheta/TwoVariable.lean` (at the current version, commit `bf62a22`) takes about 30 seconds. Merging #11980 brings this down to 26 seconds. This is not quite as much of a speedup as adding Michael's list of explicit custom instances (23 sec on my machine), but it's not too far off.
> 
> I think merging in the long list of explicit instances would probably be judged as contravening mathlib's "house style" (especially given the conclusion of the recent zulip debate "To automate or not to automate?", where several prominent members of the community argued strongly that we should use automated systems whenever possible and tolerate some slow-down as a result). Other than that, I don't think there's much more that can be done to speed it up.
> 
> May I suggest that we wait on #11980, and when that is merged, we merge this as it is?

I tend to agree. It would be good, however, to solve the underlying problem. See also [here](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/simp.20prefers.20CharP.2Ecast_eq_zero.20over.20Nat.2Ecast_zero/near/431783744) on Zulip.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#11980~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8600764185/job/23566408484)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8600764185/job/23566407646)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8600764185/job/23566408170)
Can the two `rw`s be combined?
Not directly, because the second one is working on a different goal. I rearranged the proof a bit to clarify (getting rid of an `erw` in the process).
(what I suggested does not work here)
(same)

```suggestion
    · exact_mod_cast Int.le_self_sq |n|
```
(less than half the hearbeats...)

```suggestion
    refine fun h ↦ h.norm.of_norm_bounded_eventually _ ?_
```
This `refine` costs 15000 heartbeats... 
In fact, it is `h.norm`. Maybe some shortcut instances for `ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ` would help?

Yes, this is very annoying. Lean seems to take a ludicrously long time (about 2 seconds) to infer `FiniteDimensional ℝ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ)`. I tried adding some extra instances but this seems to make the problem worse, not better.

I think most lemmas stating junk values are named using the junk value (`..._eq_zero_of_...` or so), but it appears that there are eight occurrences of `..._undef` in similar lemmas already in Mathlib.
In my opinion, `_undef` makes some sense here, but it would be nice to have more consistency...

The statement is twice as long as the proof. Does it makes sense to inline this below?
(If you think it helps structuring the proof as it is, then it is fine to leave it.)
Inlining it actually makes the proof quicker, and I don't think it's any less clear, so I'll do that – thanks!
Does `rwa ... at step4` work here? (it does.)

There is some repetition here (compare the proof of `hasFDerivAt_jacobiTheta₂`).
Is there a general principle that can be extracted?
I'm not sure, I didn't see a nice way of unifying them (without adding extra bulk to the arguments).

```suggestion
lemma jacobiTheta₂_add_left' (z τ : ℂ) :
```

```suggestion
    jacobiTheta₂' (z + τ) τ =
      cexp (-π * I * (τ + 2 * z)) * (jacobiTheta₂' z τ - 2 * π * I * jacobiTheta₂ z τ) := by
```

Is there a reason why there are two `rw`s instead of one?
(I see that combining them would likely not save a line, so it's OK either way.)

They're not working on the same goal. The original goal is closed by `mul_zero`; but `jacobiTheta₂_undef` has spawned a new side goal of proving `(-1 / τ).im ≤ 0` which the last two lines deal with.

I'll rewrite it with an explicit `have` for the side goal.
Use `z` instead of `x` (as in the code)? (Similarly below for the derivative.)
Why is this necessary now if it wasn't before?
The imports in `JacobiTheta.TwoVariable` changed, so `RemovableSingularity` is no longer transitively imported here and the import needs to be added explicitly.

```suggestion
  cexp (2 * π * I * n * z + π * I * n ^ 2 * τ) •
    ((2 * π * I * n) • (ContinuousLinearMap.fst ℂ ℂ ℂ) +
      (π * I * n ^ 2) • (ContinuousLinearMap.snd ℂ ℂ ℂ))
```
Not sure what the style guide says, but I find this more readable (and the outer parens are not necessary).

```suggestion
  simp only [norm_mul, Complex.norm_eq_abs, Complex.abs_two, abs_I,
```
is slightly faster.

```suggestion
  conv =>
    enter [1, n]
    rw [show -(-π * (T * n ^ 2 - 2 * S * n) - -1 * n) = n * (π * T * n - (2 * π * S + 1)) by ring]
```
makes the proof twice as fast (the `convert` is fairly slow).

```suggestion
      conv =>
        enter [1, n]
        rw [show -π * n ^ 2 * τ.im - 2 * π * n * z.im =
              n * (n * (-π * τ.im) - 2 * π * z.im) by ring]
```
is again a bit faster.
This is fairly slow (~ 13500 heartbeats), probably because of type class inference. Not sure much can be done about that.
(Most of this time seems to be spent in inferring `SMul ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ)`.)
With a lot of local instances, this gets below 6000 heartbeats. (More details later.)

Rewriting with `norm_smul` costs nearly 7000 heartbeats. Would it help to have a local specialized version of that? You need it three times in this proof (which currently eats close to 30000 heartbeats). E.g.,
```lean
  have hns (a : ℂ) (f : (ℂ × ℂ) →L[ℂ] ℂ) : ‖a • f‖ = ‖a‖ * ‖f‖ :=
    norm_smul a f
```
and then use `hns` three times. `hns` still costs 10000 heartbeats (I think this is because some instances need to be unified [possibly `@instHSMul ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) SMulZeroClass.toSMul =?= @instHSMul ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) ContinuousLinearMap.instSMul`]), but the total goes down by almost 50%.
Thanks, this does indeed speed things up quite a lot

This line costs 60000 heartbeats (!)
It looks like trying shortcut instances could really speed things up...
For some reason, it is vastly quicker (several orders of magnitude) to use `IsPreconnected.prod` and then apply `Convex.isPreconnected` to the factors.
This last `convert` is also somewhat heavy.
fixed
~ 17000 heartbeats
I tried squeezing the `simps` to `simp only` and somehow this actually made it _slower_! Whatever is taking the time, it isn't the two `simp` calls.
~ 20000 heartbeats
`by apply` is a little quicker (but still quite slow overall).
PS Actually `by apply` is actually a _lot_ quicker (it's just that the proof is still slow overall because of other steps). So I'm going to mark this one as "resolved".
~ 10000 heartbeats
now squeezed
`field_simp` is slow, but it's a fairly complicated equation, so it's probably OK.

```suggestion
    (2 * π : ℂ) * I * n * z + π * I * n ^ 2 * τ = (π * (2 * n) :) * z * I + (π * n ^ 2 :) * τ * I),
```
-300 heartbeats (avoid trying to find a coercion from ℂ to ℝ)

```suggestion
    Summable (fun n : ℤ ↦ (|n| ^ k : ℝ) * Real.exp (-π * (T * n ^ 2 - 2 * S * |n|))) := by
  suffices Summable (fun n : ℕ ↦ (n ^ k : ℝ) * Real.exp (-π * (T * n ^ 2 - 2 * S * n))) by
```
-500 heartbeats (here it is ℝ to ℤ)

Squeezing the `simp`s speeds this up slightly. `set_option profiler true in set_option profiler.threshold in` shows (among others things) `aesop took 125ms`. Maybe it is used in some automatically filled fields?

Looks like `aesop` is being called by `continuity` to prove that the given linear map is continuous. I've substituted an explicit proof term (generated by using `continuity?` and then golfing the result a bit).

The `continuity` call takes the bulk of the time (~20000 heartbeats). This is a lot faster:
```suggestion
    unfold jacobiTheta₂'_term jacobiTheta₂_term
    fun_prop
```

```suggestion
  simp_rw [jacobiTheta₂_term, Equiv.neg_apply, Int.cast_neg, neg_sq, mul_assoc, neg_mul_neg]
```
Squeezing this `simp` gains ~700 heartbeats.

I have added
```lean
instance : CharZero ℤ := StrictOrderedSemiring.to_charZero
instance : CharZero ℝ := RCLike.charZero_rclike
instance : Module ℂ ℂ := NormedSpace.toModule
instance : Module ℂ (ℂ × ℂ) := Prod.instModule
instance : AddCommMonoid ℂ := inferInstance
instance : AddCommMonoid (ℂ × ℂ) := inferInstance
instance : TopologicalSpace ℂ := inferInstance
instance : TopologicalSpace (ℂ × ℂ) := inferInstance
instance : SMul ℝ ℂ := Algebra.toSMul
instance : SMul ℂ ℂ := Algebra.toSMul
instance : Module ℝ ℂ := instModule
instance : MulActionWithZero ℂ ℂ := MonoidWithZero.toMulActionWithZero ℂ
instance : MulAction ℂ ℂ := MulActionWithZero.toMulAction
instance : SMulCommClass ℂ ℂ ℂ := smulCommClass_self ℂ ℂ
instance : ContinuousConstSMul ℂ ℂ := SMulCommClass.continuousConstSMul
instance : ContinuousConstSMul ℝ ℂ :=
  UniformContinuousConstSMul.to_continuousConstSMul ℝ ℂ
instance : IsScalarTower ℂ ℂ ℂ := IsScalarTower.right
instance : IsScalarTower ℝ ℂ ℂ := IsScalarTower.complexToReal
instance : SMulCommClass ℂ ℝ ℂ := IsScalarTower.to_smulCommClass'
instance : AddCommGroup (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.addCommGroup
instance : AddCommMonoid (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.addCommMonoid
instance : Module ℝ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.module
instance : Module ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.module
instance : SMul ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.instSMul
instance : NormedSpace ℝ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := ContinuousLinearMap.toNormedSpace
instance : FiniteDimensional ℂ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := inferInstance
instance : FiniteDimensional ℝ (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ) := FiniteDimensional.complexToReal (ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ)
```
This is certainly not very nice (and probably some of these are not very important), but it avoids a lot of slow type class synthesis tasks throughout the file.

Generally, it seems like everything involving `ℂ × ℂ →L[ℂ] ℂ` is prone to slow type class inference issues...
Does #11980 help here?
@riccardobrasca It does help considerably, which is why Michael and I made it a prereq for this PR; but now it's merged.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(ModularForms/JacobiTheta): derivative of theta function
